components.html: You'll find information about what to do now based on the answers you've given.

## You said the problem had affected your health 

Contact your local council if you're not able to continue living in your home because it's making you unwell. They may be able to help arrange emergency housing.  Make sure you keep sick notes and hospital reports. 

### Claim compensation for damage to your health

You can claim if your physical or mental health is affected by the conditions in your home.

The amount depends on how you were affected and for how long.

You can also claim for:

- loss of earnings if you were unable to work
- extra expenses such as prescriptions or travel to hospital

Visit the [Shelter website for more information](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/housing_disrepair_check_if_you_can_claim_compensation)

## You said the problem may be serious enough for an emergency court order 

Asking the court to order that repairs be done immediately can only be done when the problem is extremely serious. 

You should consider getting professional legal advice before starting an application. You can get information on finding a solicitor and other sources of legal help in [useful resources](/future-resources)   

You can also find out more about [what to do if your landlord won't do repairs](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/legal_action_if_your_landlord_wont_do_repairs) on the Shelter website. 

### Contact your local council 
You should also contact your local council if the problem is urgent. Find out more about [contacting your local council](/local-council-detail)

## Your landlord should not evict you because you asked for repairs to be done 

Your landlord has to keep your home in a good condition and do repairs if you need them. They canâ€™t make you leave your home just for asking for repairs to be done - your landlord has to follow a proper eviction process if they want you to leave. 

Find out more about this on the [Shelter website](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/revenge_eviction_if_you_ask_for_repairs)

## Your landlord may not enter your home without notice 

It is against the law for landlords to enter your home without giving you notice. It is also against the law for them to arrange for anyone else to enter your home, eg builders, without giving you notice. 

Find out more about this on the [Shelter website](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/repairs_and_inspections_access_to_your_rented_home)

## You said you may consider taking legal action 

Going to court can be expensive and time-consuming, but it is an option if you have not been able to resolve the problem in another way. You may want to talk to a solicitor or qualified legal professional before you start any legal action. 

There is a process you need to follow to make a claim. Find out more about [taking legal action](/legal-action-detail)

## You need to tell your landlord or letting agent about the problem 

You can find out more about [writing to your landlord](/writing-to-landlord) including links to letter templates. 

Remember to keep copies of any letters you send, and the dates you sent them.

## You need to contact your landlord or letting agent in writing 

Even if you have already told your landlord about the problem over the phone, by text message or in person, you need to tell them again in writing. This can be by email or letter. 

Find out more about [writing to your landlord](writing-to-landlord)

## Contact your local council 

You should contact the housing team at your local council. They have an obligation to make sure that tenants are living in properties that are looked after by landlords, and kept in a reasonable state of repair.

You can find your local council using this service: [https://www.gov.uk/find-local-council](https://www.gov.uk/find-local-council)

Find out more about [contacting your council](/local-council-detail)

## Write to your landlord or letting agent again

If you have waited a reasonable amount of time (usually this is 10 working days), you should write to your landlord again. 

Find out more about [contacting your landlord again](/writing-to-landlord-again)

## Contact your local council again

If you have contacted your local council and they have not responded or have not helped to fix the problem, you should contact them again.  

Find out more about [contacting your local council again](/contact-council-again)

## Know your rights and your landlord's responsibilities 

Check whether your landlord or letting agent is responsible for the problem you told us about in [your rights and your landlord's responsibilities](/rights-responsibilities).

## You could consider working with a mediator  

A mediator will work with both you and your landlord so that you can find a solution everyone agrees with. 

Mediation is usually less costly than taking legal action. 

For more information about how mediation works and to find a mediator, visit [www.civilmediation.org](http://www.civilmediation.org)

## Get ready for going to court 

Before going to court, you should try to gather as much information as you can about your case. 

[See more about getting ready for court](/court-expert-detail)

## Future steps and useful resources 

Get more information on [future steps](/future-resources) to help address the problem.
